title: هل أصبحت مشاكل النوم سمة عصرنا الحالي؟

segments.text: This is a podcast worth paying attention to from BBC Arabic News.
And I am Omar Hassan.
I welcome our guest today, Dr. Ahmed Khamis.
A specialist in psychiatry and addiction treatment, welcome.
Good evening and welcome, Mr. Omar.
To start, let's ask what sleep is.
Or rather, they say that the ideal number of sleep hours, or the golden hours of sleep, is eight hours.
How accurate is this theory?
First of all, let me thank you for this invitation.
And before I answer your question about whether eight hours is really sufficient for sleep?
What do we understand about sleep?
Sleep is a physiological process during which the body's functions generally rest, characterized by a lack of awareness and sensation.
Sleep helps the body to compensate for the loss of energy throughout the day, during work and daily activities.
Here, I am talking about the loss during the day.
Why? Because the body or the brain is programmed to wake up during the day and sleep at night.
Here, of course, we see the problems faced by people who have to work night shifts.
Perhaps many of us look back positively to the past, to the time before social media and mobile phones.
And we remember how we used to go to bed early and perhaps sleep for longer hours.
Scientifically speaking, are people really sleeping less than they did fifty years ago, for example?
So here, I want to answer your question and the previous one as well; we were just discussing the topic of sleep duration.
The most striking thing about sleep is the number of hours.
When someone wants to assess their sleep, they say, 'I slept for two hours yesterday, and I was awake the whole time; I slept for three hours.'
Honestly, yesterday I managed to get 12 hours of sleep.
So, it's not simply just about the number of hours of sleep.
Unfortunately, there are people whose number of sleep hours remains constant, but the quality of their sleep changes.
Here, I am talking about sleep quality because it is a very important factor.
Because in the end, just as the number of hours is important, one should have slept well and benefited from their sleep.
Not waking up feeling broken, tired, or with a scattered mind as if they hadn't slept at all.
Unfortunately, studies are showing that in recent years, the quality of sleep among people in general has been declining.
Especially in the last few years, and there are many reasons for this that we can discuss shortly.
Yes, we might come to the topic of sleep quality, but regarding the number of hours of sleep.
Perhaps the evidence is not sufficient to say that people are sleeping for fewer hours.
However, regarding sleep quality, yes, indeed, a few months ago, Sleep Cycle published.
It is the company behind one of the most popular sleep tracking apps, which conducted an analysis based on user data over two years.
They found that there is a decline in sleep quality worldwide between the years 2023 and 2024.
Well, perhaps for listeners who do not know what sleep quality means.
What does it mean?
That's a great question to understand the topic of sleep quality and how natural sleep works.
Natural sleep primarily operates within an internal clock programmed in the brain for the purpose of sleep.
And it relies on a key gland that receives information primarily from the amount of light it is exposed to.
Or the eyes are exposed to it during the day, and the absence of this light at night.
In addition to stress hormones, which are at higher levels during the day, such as cortisol.
And their decrease in the evening also enhances the process of sleep.
So if you noticed, I was just telling you about how the internal lighting of the eye determines the function of this gland.
And it gives it a signal whether I am in the daytime or nighttime.
That's why our presence recently, or the habit that has developed among people of being in front of screens, whether they are television or mobile phone screens,
This sends signals to the brain that there is still high light and brightness in front of you, so stay awake, and this disrupts sleep quality, of course.
Yes, do you think that some newly developed habits, such as browsing social media and short videos or reels,
affect sleep in general, impact sleep quality, and perhaps the ability to wake up during sleep.
Of course, of course.
Alright, I hear many friends or colleagues say that they don't have a problem with sleep itself, but they find it difficult to transition from being awake to sleeping.
They toss and turn in bed for a long time, unlike how it was years ago when they say we used to fall asleep quickly.
Are these just personal experiences for them, or is it actually a phenomenon?
Sleep problems are evident; they are on the rise, as indicated by studies or people's complaints, as you mentioned.
Of course, there are many tips we can discuss regarding this particular topic.
But I also want to touch on another topic, which is the increasing stress in our lives.
The global events we are going through and the amount of news we hear throughout the day from around the world.
This keeps people's stress and alertness levels very high, and this is generally noticeable.
This, in itself, disrupts the sleep process, as we mentioned earlier; these hormone levels need to drop to a certain point.
So that they can be replaced by the hormones that assist in the sleep process.
I mean, do you think we shouldn't solely blame social media here?
Perhaps there are significant changes in contemporary lifestyle, such as increasing work pressures and life demands, and so on.
Such things affect sleep.
Definitely, of course, definitely.
Of course, and I would add to that the general atmosphere of the surrounding news or the world as a whole.
News is distressing on an individual level and frightening for people, keeping them always on edge, whether it's about wars or economic news.
Or in general news, there is always high tension around the world during this period.
So, from your personal observations and your review of scientific studies, have sleep problems become more common among younger generations?
Meaning teenagers or younger youth.
Is it more prevalent among them compared to older age groups, for example?
Generally speaking, sleep problems increase with age.
And not the other way around.
You could look at it from the perspective that the use of digital devices might be more prevalent among younger age groups.
And their stress levels are higher because, for example, a young person in their twenties is thinking about their life, future, and what they want to do.
This is different from someone who is in their sixties or seventies.
However, with aging, sleep problems do arise.
So, each age group has its own issues, and even the topic of mobile phones is no longer limited to the youth.
Now, everyone is using them; it’s not restricted by age.
Everyone has their phone in hand, scrolling through reels; this issue is no longer just associated with younger age groups.
Exactly, it’s truly a cross-generational problem; it’s not limited to a specific group.
Sure, we can talk.
Well, an article came out recently in The Lancet magazine describing sleep problems as a neglected public health issue.
It discusses many concerning statistics, but it refers to a study conducted in the United Kingdom.
It states that among those who experienced actual symptoms of insomnia, only 17% were diagnosed with sleep-related issues.
And perhaps this leads us to the topic of people's reluctance to visit the doctor.
For those suffering from sleep problems, at what point should they consider seeing a doctor?
Look, let me tell you something; you’re talking about it as an important issue to me.
So, I say that this is a topic that concerns every human being on the face of the earth.
Because who among us doesn't sleep? Who among us doesn't need sleep?
The problem is that even the slightest sleep disturbance in a normal person leaves an impact on their daily life.
And now let's think on a personal level, who among us hasn't been affected by their sleep at least once in a day, a night, or a week?
During that time, how much did it affect their mental state and daily life?
Here we're talking about normal individuals, now let's discuss mental disorders.
First, let's talk about psychological disorders.
Most psychological disorders are related to mental health issues or even addiction problems.
A person who is stressed will have their sleep affected.
A person who is depressed will have their sleep affected.
A person with bipolar disorder will have their sleep affected.
A person who uses substances will experience sleep disturbances.
This is aside from the fact that sleep itself has its own specific disorders.
A person may have a disorder that is solely related to sleep.
In the sleep pattern or in the way one sleeps.
Or in issues that are solely related to sleep.
It is certainly a problem that might be somewhat overlooked.
Or not receiving the necessary attention.
And there are simple tips that we can touch on shortly, if you’d like.
Perhaps we can save these tips for the end of the podcast.
But you made an important point a moment ago.
That sleep problems may be a symptom of a psychological issue.
And sometimes it may be a problem in itself.
Yes, that's correct.
We can categorize them as either primary sleep problems or secondary ones.
Or they could be secondary to a psychological disorder.
Not a psychological disorder.
Great.
Well, you just touched on a point.
That some people might say they feel moody.
Because they didn't have a restful sleep the night before.
But in the long term, can sleep problems themselves lead to
more serious mental and psychological issues?
Undoubtedly, this accumulation of fatigue and stress.
As we mentioned at the beginning of the episode, sleep is a means for the body.
To rest both mentally and physically.
If you strain your body, mind, and spirit over a long period of time.
You will inevitably become more susceptible to psychological disorders.
After such a level of stress.
Yes, perhaps these tensions or psychological pressures caused by lack of sleep can lead to bigger problems.
So, what about magnesium supplements?
It's become common to find them next to the bed of each one of us.
Many doctors recommend them as a dietary supplement that aids sleep.
Is there scientific evidence supporting its effectiveness in overcoming sleep issues?
Alright, magnesium is primarily a dietary supplement.
Okay?
Alright.
It's not a medication; it's a dietary supplement.
Magnesium comes in many forms.
The form that actually plays a role in sleep is magnesium glycinate.
This is an important piece of information for people.
Not just any magnesium will help me sleep.
Because magnesium has many types.
The existing evidence is more promising than it is proven.
This means promising evidence that it helps with the process of sleeping and body relaxation.
There is no harm in using it.
In many cases, we use it.
However, harm can occur when we use it to cover up a problem.
This means if I am using it incorrectly.
If there is a problem I need to address and I am running away from treating it.
The problem is that I am using a dietary supplement like magnesium.
This is where the problem arises.
But there is not that much fear surrounding it.
However, its effectiveness in aiding sleep may be proven for certain disorders or conditions.
I mean, let me say that aside from the evidence proving that it is a promising supplement.
People have had good experiences with it.
It seems that in clinical observations, people have reported feeling improvements in their sleep.
Yes, that's correct.
Great, great.
Well, perhaps for those listening to this podcast while trying to sleep.
We should ask about this habit.
The habit of sleeping while listening to a podcast or any other audio clip.
How do we explain this phenomenon?
How can someone sleep while listening to something?
This means that many young people can only sleep with the sound of a podcast beside them.
Or they might have a specific program that they prefer to keep for sleeping.
Of course, this is a common phenomenon.
It can be explained primarily as a way to calm the brain by focusing on an external stimulus.
So when you listen to the podcast and focus on it, you distract your mind from the anxiety within.
Another reason is that there is something called working memory.
It is responsible for holding and processing information immediately.
When you engage with a podcast or something audible, there is no longer room for it to focus on the issue that worries it.
There is also a system in the brain called the default mode network and the stress response system.
This is related to the conditions of the mind and thinking about the past, self, and future.
These are the thoughts that often come to someone right before they sleep, like what I want to do and what has happened to me, and so on.
So these also get scattered when there is a podcast or some sound playing.
There is also something called conditioning, which is a conditioned association.
For example, I am used to sleeping on this pillow, accustomed to my bed and my blanket.
If it changes, I don't know how to sleep.
The same thing happens here; the podcast or this sound becomes associated with sleep.
So if I hear this sound, it means it's time for sleep, and that becomes subconscious.
Also, the topic of emotional safety and virtual existence.
This sound might provide an unconscious feeling of safety and companionship for the person.
This reduces feelings of loneliness and stress.
And I want to specifically talk about the topic of podcasts and audio.
This topic isn't as intimidating as reels are.
The problem with reels is that they are videos, have high lighting, are very short, and require a lot of focus.
They also have fluctuations and change topics rapidly.
Whereas a podcast is just audio without light or the need for a person to look at a screen.
So it's a gentler option; I can tell people that if they must use electronics before sleeping, it’s better to stick to audio only.
Or perhaps they could follow my strategy for sleep, which is to read boring things or things I don't care much about, so I escape into sleep.
So perhaps this is another strategy.
Well, as a psychiatrist, if I told you that I don't sleep enough, don't get good sleep, and toss and turn for a long time in bed.
What advice can you give me?
Alright, from my perspective as a psychologist, my advice is to approach the issue fundamentally.
That is, treating sleep or focusing on it happens in the hours leading up to bedtime; it's not just a push of a button.
I mean, if I start thinking about why I have sleep issues when I lay my head on the pillow, it won't get resolved like that.
I need to start thinking about the hours leading up to sleep.
First, I need a healthy lifestyle that includes enough exercise and activity throughout the day.
And I should avoid stimulants and smoking, especially in the hours before sleep.
Also, as you mentioned a moment ago, it's important to set aside time for relaxation before bed.
Now, we have a problem in our lives these days where we are under high stress from television, mobile phones, and so on.
Suddenly, with news and everything, we go straight to sleep without a break.
It's always important to have a break where you can read, spend time with family, or just relax.
This also helps with sleep.
A very important topic is separating the bed from daily life.
What does that mean? It means the bed is only for sleeping, not for studying, working, or anything else.
When you use your bed to sit on during the day to do work, finish tasks, or study, it complicates things.
This also makes it harder to sleep, so one should only go to bed at bedtime.
Also, managing anxiety and thoughts.
There’s a technique or a simple thing one can do.
People often feel that if they are going to worry, it happens before sleep.
Thoughts, worries, and fears all come to mind right before sleep.
So there's a simple thing that one can do.
You write down these ideas, the things you're thinking about, on a piece of paper.
And you say, 'Okay, I will think about these one, two, three, four tomorrow morning.'
So after you write them down, your brain relaxes from the burden it was carrying.
The topic of consistency is very, very, very important.
I always maintain a certain routine.
I go to sleep at this time and wake up at that time.
This is something that people who stay up late on weekends struggle with.
Some people have a life rhythm where they come to the weekend.
They might stay up until the morning.
I sleep until noon the next day.
I start at the beginning of the week.
During the first two days of the week, I just adjust my sleep that got disrupted over the weekend.
So, maintaining a regular sleep schedule is very important.
That's great, great.
Thank you very much, Dr. Ahmed Khamis.
And to our listeners, thank you for following along.
Share your opinions and comments with us on our social media accounts.
And let your friends know that this podcast is worth paying attention to.
You can watch episodes of 'Worth Paying Attention To' on the BBC News Arabic channel on YouTube and on Spotify.
Or listen and download on your favorite podcast platforms.
And on our website bbcarabic.com.
In the editorial management for today's episode, Karima Kawah.
And I was with you in preparing and presenting the episode, Omar Hassan.
Timing and translation by Nancy Qanqar.
